title: Will conservatives retain their majority in the Majles after Iran's upcoming parliamentary elections?
preds: Dropping to match graph - my way of trying to mitigate the outcome in a neutral manner.

The elections occurred without any major demonstrations or security incidents, but an Interior Ministry official confirmed that a conflict among “candidates’ supporters” caused a shooting that wounded four people in Fars province. The runoff elections will determine 68 seats in the 290-member Parliament. The reformist-moderate bloc made major gains during the first round of elections in February to the detriment of the hardliners. No single faction won an outright majority, however, so the runoff elections will be crucial in determining Parliament’s final political makeup. Interior Ministry Spokesman Hossein Ali Amiri told reporters that election results will be announced on April 30, although he noted that this date could change. Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif wrote an open letter to UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon in which he called upon the UN to intervene in a recent U.S. Supreme Court ruling permitting terrorist attack victims to collect $2 billion in frozen Iranian assets. Zarif accused the U.S. of “undermining the rule of law” and stated that Iran holds the U.S. “responsible for this outrageous robbery, disguised under a court order, and is determined to take every lawful measure to restore the stolen property and the interest accrued to it.” There seem to be different interpretation of tentative (unofficial results) by various news agencies.  Reuters has reported (in my opinion, a long record of accuracy in its data and reported information) the following results: Conservatives (First Round) : 112     ;  (Second Round) :  10  =  122
Moderates (First Round)  :  90      ;  (Second Round) :   36    =  126
Independents (First Round)  29  ;  (Second Round) :    20    =   49 Various combinations of outcomes are possible.  First, Conservatives win the four remaining seats, giving it a total of 126 (a tie with moderates).
Second, Conservative could loose 4 seats to Moderates, giving it a total of 130 (winning a majority over Conservatives).
Third, both Conservative and Moderates could win 2 seats each, leading to a tie (neither party gains a majority).
Fourth, seats for Independents could determine a win for Moderates and a loss for Conservatives, or alternatively the other way around depending on their alignment. There are however still 4 seats that have not been reported and counting continues.  The current 3 seat (unofficial lead) by the Moderates should not be view as the official count, but it possible that it could meet the data for the official counts.   BBC has widely reported a major win for Moderates and conflates the voting bloc between it an Independents (although there is no formal alliance - Independents tend to vote for the regime, ie., the Supreme Leader and the Principlists).   This conflation confuses the reality of the count by correctly implies that the voting patterns in the new parliament will be determined vote by vote.  If the Principlists win a majority of the 11 seats it is bound to maintain it's majority in the Majles.

I do not think that this question can be resolved fairly; I think it should be voided, or that Brier & Accuracy scores on it should not be calculated into averages.

How ideological orientations are determined among qualified candidates for election purposes will be the primary determinant to the outcome of this question.  Alliances, ideological labels, parliamentary voting patterns and pressure from IRGC and regime proponents will shape the direction that each parliamentary candidate asserts.    For example, moderate in Iran can be determined on a scale itself which include conservatives with a flavor of Principalist orientation.   How can such a candidate be classified if their ideological orientation is, for example, reformist but also pro-regime (ie., religious conservative assuming the central governance structure of theocracy)?  Are they reformist?  Are they moderates?  Are they principalist?   The inability of correct classification for electoral purposes is further constrained by the fact that there are no political parties (in the sense of western democracies).  Can one conclude that it is simply a theocratic political structure (at its core), an autocratic governance structure, and coercion through Sharia Law?  This makes for a messy attempt to classify and determine who has in fact dominated the electoral outcome.   Since rural Iran is largely oriented toward principalist sentiments, one should expect a shift toward further gains by conservatives.    Western media interpretations of the situation further complicates the classification of political orientation by candidates and alignments by using western orientations to make sense of the Persian political interactions.
Given the absolute annihilation in the Tehran elections for the conservatives and the previous vote going against them, I suspect they could be routed.

As the articles below indicate, being on a list does not necessarily indicate a candidate's ideology. http://www.theguardian.com/world/iran-blog/2016/apr/22/iran-runoff-parliamentary-elections-tehranbureau
"In the past, the reform movement gave up when its candidates were disqualified. No longer. This time they have not given up even when their first-round candidate was defeated, but rather have recruited from among the remaining candidates. This means a candidate who ran as an independent or even fundamentalist in the first round can end up on the ‘Second List of Hope’ running against a more radical fundamentalist. One Iranian activist puts it this way: after buses leave the terminals in Iran they stop for a second time at the edge of the city and offer discounted prices on any remaining seats. This is what the reform movement is doing. Having to go with a half-empty bus to the elections (because of disqualifications) it has acquired the habit of picking ‘in-between’ candidates, non-ideological moderates, or even ‘rational’ fundamentalists. This is a discounted ticket on the bus of reform. Prospects look good. The reformists calculate that the fundamentalists have already reached their maximum capacity of voters. They believe that fundamentalist voters were more likely than others to have responded to the calls to vote from supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who has compared casting a ballot to a religious duty like daily prayers. The 38% of electors who did not show up to vote in February appeared indifferent to Khamenei’s entreaties – and hence were either apolitical or politically-disposed boycotters. Reformers, then, could be right in thinking there are no more fundamentalists left to bring out for the second round. This leaves a decisive majority of potential second-round voters susceptible to the reformist call for incremental change along the lines President Hassan Rouhani has been pursuing since elected in 2013. The bus is leaving soon." And also,

An Iranian elections analyst has provided a recent assessment of where matters stand with the election and outcomes not including the pending April 29 electoral outcomes.   His assessment indicates that : "Reformists did not “sweep” the Iranian elections on February 26 for Parliament and the Assembly of Experts. Hardliners suffered humiliating losses in both bodies. Two of the Assembly’s most notorious hardliners, including its current chairman, were defeated while hardliner parliamentarians lost every seat in Tehran to a moderate-reformist bloc formed days before the election. But the pro-Rouhani bloc will not win a majority in either body, and by no means will all members who ran on pro-Rouhani lists actually support the president’s policies. Iranians voted for the reformist idea, but the vetting process prevented them from electing a reformist parliament. Preliminary results for Parliament indicate that the moderate-reformist bloc has won 83 seats; hardline Principlists have won 78; independents formally unaffiliated with any faction have won 60; and 64 seats will be filled in runoff elections scheduled for April. The elections’ precise effect thus remains to be seen. Iran does not have political parties, and participation on an electoral list does not bind parliamentarians to vote in a certain way once elected.  The factional composition of the next parliament thus does not suggest that President Hassan Rouhani will have reliable support for all of his policies. If this assessment is correct, the most likely outcomes for the IFP  moves in favor of the 'hardliners/principalists.'

Hardline conservatives have been left significantly weakened. This leaves open the very strong possibility that the next parliament and assembly will be less hardline. Even if hardliners eventually gain a majority in parliament following the runoffs, their leadership vacuum leaves their effectiveness as a bloc in question. Moreover the entry of the Hope List, made up of centrists, reformists, and traditional conservatives, into parliament is likely to make the legislature somewhat more politically diverse and, in the absence of the polarization of the past, maybe even more technocratic. While centrists and traditional conservatives in the Hope List are unlikely to support sweeping social and political changes sought by reformists, a victory for this list is likely to lessen resistance to President Hassan Rouhani’s economic and foreign policy agenda in parliament.
https://majlismonitor.com/en/2016/03/analysis-2016-iranian-parliamentary-assembly-of-experts-election-results/ Last month’s elections for Iran’s parliament and Assembly of Experts were complicated by the elaborate and extensive vetting procedure that filters out candidates considered too radical for the system. The overwhelming majority of those disqualified candidates belonged to the progressive end of the spectrum, usually referred to as reformists. Yet despite the authorities’ efforts to manage the outcome, Iran’s hard-liners still lost their majority in Iran’s 290-member parliament, or Majlis, while moderates won a majority in the Assembly of Experts, the clerical body tasked with choosing the next supreme leader. Key hard-liners, including two prominent clerics from the Assembly of Experts, were voted out.

It seems to me that @Anneinak was right a few days ago, or at least on to something. We and the administrators are attempting to define what a "conservative" is in this election, without really understanding the cultural context, or what Iranians understand to be "conservatism," "moderation," and "liberalism." So we wind up reading our own assumptions into the question, then bean counting which party controls how many seats. Since "conservative" has no actual definition in this question, I think it should be voided. When it comes down to it, Zoroastrian monarchists are arguably the most conservative Iranians there are, but that's obviously not what the administrators mean. But it just goes to show that it's all a matter of definitions.

What's a poor forecaster to do?  I see reports that call out so-called moderate candidates for being conservatives in disguise.  I see reports about elected members of the Majlis who are expected to work with moderates somehow, but who are also expected to stand firm on conservative matters like women's issues, hard-core opposition to the West, and missile launches.  I'm not sure how one can tell who is and who isn't a conservative now.  There are no firm party affiliations that can be tallied.  This matter seems to have devolved into a bet on how GJO will adjudicate, rather than a bet on the original question.
Love the @Anneinak comment about the fluid Eastern circular system.  Who's a conservative?  Who's a reformist?  Who knows?  I'm so glad not to be the person who has to score this question.

The original Washington Post logic.* Four categories segregated into two camps
Camp #1. The Moderates = {reformists, centrists}
Camp #2. The Principlists = {traditional-conservatives. hardline-conservatives}
Constraints:
a) The traditional-conservatives and the hardline-conservatives together had a majority.
b) The traditional-conservatives were the "swing group." They would align either with the Moderate camp or the hardliner-conservatives depending upon the issue. It was the traditional-conservatives that aligned with the Moderate camp to work with Rhouhani to get the nuclear deal done. Therefore, any statement that whether a parliamentarian sided with Rhouhani would be discriminate between the Principlist camp and the Moderate camp cannot be correct. (@Khalid) Note that there is no reference whatsoever to any "independents" in the WaPo scheme. The WikiPedia page has four groupings: Principlist (167), Independent (88), Reformist (26), and Other (9). Note that there is no reference to the category "centrists." Issues:
1) The term "moderate" is used in the WaPo scheme as the name of a camp. Most reports seem to use it as a name of a category.
2) The WaPo scheme makes no reference to "independents" whatsoever.
3) The term "centrist" as used in the WaPo scheme does not seem to be used in any other scheme or report.
4) It might be possible to substitute "independents" for "centrists," but this seems simplistic and dangerous.
5) No reports reference traditional-conservatives, but instead seem to use the term moderate-conservatives.
6) Larijana was cited in the WaPo article as a traditional-conservative. The Atlantic source now designates him as "pragmatist." I'm not laying out any solution here, but only a listing of those definitions and constraints that might need to be considered to develop a solution. That these parliamentarians may align themselves idiosyncratically in reference to a particular issue and are therefore not amenable to any static categorical grouping should not be dismissed. It's a nuanced, evolving, parliament and I think we all understand that. I just would not want the resolution of this question to be a bungled square peg jammed into a round hole. If it doesn't work, it doesn't work. * The recent Atlantic article uses the exact same organizational scheme as the Washington Post.
http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/03/iran-election-results-winner/472128/ This Atlantic article also, however, introduces a number of nuances that need to be considered. It introduces a new category of "pragmatists." The List of Hope which has somehow been labeled "the" reformist list (because that was the list that contained the reformists) actually also contains a "majority of these folks are unknown quantities, and a few of them actually self-identify as conservatives." A truly "unknown quantity" who, at best, is a "List of Hope Listee" is very problematic. As I read this Atlantic article, it sounds to me that Sadjadpour is politely saying (between the lines): "the categories you wish to use simply do not apply" (on a reliable and consistent basis suitable for ideological identification). If this is true, I sincerely hope that GJ does not insist upon forcing them to apply. Edit: @000 - You're right. April run-offs extend the closing. I overlooked that. Quite apart from joint lists and the fact that ‘moderate’ Principle-ists appeared to have made common cause with ‘hard-line’ reformists, this parliament witnessed the election of an unusually high number of independents with no apparent affiliation and to which each side has laid claim. Given the rigorous nature of the vetting, it is hard to see how they can be regarded as reformists. Time will tell which way they will fall. Then there are the approximately 20 per cent of seats that will be decided in the run-off, and many of these are seen as leaning towards the Principle-ists. The practical reality of this highly controlled election is of a parliament still dominated by Principle-ists of one hue or another with an overall institutional balance effectively engineered to the right of the political spectrum.

WHO’S WHO
•	with no clearly defined parties, it is a complicated task to discern where many prospective members of parliament stand in relation to government policies. 
•	The hard-liners/conservatives/”Principalists” have strict views on the enforcement of Islamic law and oppose closer relations with the outside world, including the nuclear deal.  They blame the economic stagnation on the policies of Rouhani and praise the work of the Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei in maintaining Iran’s position as a major regional power.  The conservative camp is increasingly defined by orthodoxy, and this is harming the moderates’ image among voters.
•	The moderates share some views with the Reformists, but do not like to be compared with the hard-liners, who are unpopular among the general public.  They  support the nuclear deal and the improved economic conditions to come following the lifting of sanctions.
•	Reformists will be led by a presidential candidate who stood aside in 2013 paving the way for Rouhani’s victory.
•	A middle ground list has emerged: the Voice of the Nation, led by a moderate conservative lawmaker known for his controversial positions including opposition to the ongoing house arrest of Mousavi and Karroubi.  
•	The exact numbers of candidates in the various camps is difficult to gauge, since they are spread out across hundreds of constituencies and many are relatively unknown politically. THE PROCESS
•	Iran does not follow a traditional political party system and instead relies on coalitions of candidates, with voting and campaigning usually centred on those lists rather than on individuals
•	Complex election rules allow a candidate to be on more than one list, meaning they can draw support from across the political spectrum.
•	candidates who garner 25% of the vote are elected after the first round. THE LISTS
•	The conservative list of 30 candidates for Tehran astonished political observers because  only three were relative moderates, raising eyebrows and disagreements even among conservatives.  This may ultimately lead to an unprecedented defeat for the hard-liners. A parliamentarian said, “Most top conservative candidates aren’t pleased with the published list, and many of them aren’t willing to withdraw in favor of the selected candidates, as they had previously promised.” Moreover said another, “The current published list is not defensible. It would be better if some figures that had the ability to offer [their] reputation and [add] value to the list were on the ticket.” “They don’t have much of a chance, and only five of them — at most — will manage to gain enough votes to enter the next parliament.” In sum, despite dominating the conservative ticket, it appears the hard-liners’ chances of actually winning the elections are slim. This is particularly so because many moderate candidates, such as the prominent parliamentarian Ali Motahari and Larijani, are maneuvering to assemble their own rival lists or perhaps even join the Reformists’ list.
•	Reformists, outnumbered otherwise, have formed an alliance with moderate parties close to Rouhani, after many years putting aside their differences to agree on a joint list of candidates in an unprecedented form of coalition aimed at blocking hardliners from entering the parliament.  They are led by an influential figure whose decision to stand down in the 2013 presidential election in favour of Rouhani was crucial to the later’s victory. Despite widespread disqualifications, reformists are pulling out all the stops to make sure fewer hardliners will enter the next parliament, or Majlis, according to Mohammadreza Jalaeipour, an Iranian reformist political activist now at Harvard University. “Reformists from all different parties have put aside their differences after many years to agree on a joint list of candidates in an unprecedented form of coalition aimed at blocking hardliners from entering the parliament,” he told the Guardian. The reformists’ patron is former president Mohammad Khatami, who faces restrictions on his movement and activities but is leading from behind the scenes. In Tehran, the reformists on Tuesday issued their joint list of 30 candidates they want to enter the Majlis from the capital. It is led by Mohammad Reza Aref, an influential reformist figure whose decision to stand down in the 2013 presidential election in favour of Rouhani was crucial in the moderate figure’s victory. Jalaeipour said the big challenge facing the reformers is persuading people to turn out and vote. “There have been a lot of disqualifications but they haven’t purged all the reformists. Placed together, this clearly signals no shifts or “reforms” from inside Iran can be expected from these polls, even after the “landmark” nuclear accord with the West and the expectations of ordinary Iranians rightfully raised. Due to the deceptive measures and fraud that characterizes the regime ruling Iran, the February 26 elections will most likely result in the hardliners winning a more powerful position. A manipulated elimination process in Iran grants enormous power to a small group of people who can decide nearly everything about who can run. Despite a factional political delusion and while the elections in Iran can hardly be described as anything similar to a Western-style democratic poll, a 290-member body called the “Majlis” (parliament) and 88-member Assembly of Experts are up for grabs. The latter is responsible for selecting a new “velayat-e faqih”, or supreme religious leader, a post currently held by Ali Khamenei. He is now 76 years of age and reports indicate he is suffering from major illnesses, but will remain in his post as a virtual king until his death. Around 12,000 people from across Iran signed up to take part in the parliamentary election only to see more than 7,000 disqualified by the 12-member Guardian Council. This is a body with six candidates appointed directly by the supreme leader, with the six remaining chosen by the judiciary, known for its loyalty to Khamenei and leaving no doubt in the end results. Recently, nine political parties leaning towards the faction of Rouhani and Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a former president and heavyweight inside the Iranian regime political spectrum, complained about the disqualification of 2,700 so-called “moderate” candidates for the parliament, with only 166 candidates being approved for the Assembly of Experts. Last week, reports indicated that even the grandson of Islamic Republic of Iran founder, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, could not prove his loyalty to the mullahs’ ideology, as the hardliners continue to show they will not back down from their current position of control and intend to fight head on any possible move for change. Reports indicate Hassan Khomeini’s credentials were rejected due to his close relationship with the Rafsanjani-Rouhani group. A large number of candidates were actually sent home due to their political viewpoints, Human Rights Watch reported, citing reviewed documents. Iran is far from being anything rightly defined as a democracy. Rouhani is a byproduct of this regime, without any ideas for real change. The Iranian people are truly yearning for an end to their country’s long-running isolation. Out of no other choice and in a voice of protest against the hardline establishment a very small number supported Rouhani back in 2013. However, with sanctions being lifted, the Iranian nation now has high expectations on which Rouhani has failed to deliver, even involving his campaign promises to finally grant them their God-given rights, such as freedom of speech and the release of thousands of political prisoners and journalists who remain suffering in Iran’s dungeons, according to various human rights bodies. Iran has the highest number of executions per capita in the world, not to forget the number of juveniles, according to a damning new Amnesty International report. The tight process of selecting candidates has launched a very vivid and dangerous dispute inside Iran. Khamenei himself has issued warnings against any relaxation of the anti-Western rhetoric this regime is notorious for. He strongly supported the vetting process and has already projected that his rivals will not enjoy any actual influence in the near future. Again, indications of any true change in Iran are hard to find. Despite the fact that candidates are allowed to demand an appeal for their disqualifications, any meaningful alteration in the results is hardly to be expected. Consider the controversial 2009 election, when Mahmoud Ahmadinejad was literally selected by Khamenei as the president and millions of people poured into the streets demanding their votes be respected, leaving the establishment no choice but to order a major and deadly crackdown. With no change in sight for the Iranian people, the result of the upcoming so-called elections in Iran will have unprecedented consequences for the ruling regime and the entire Middle East region. ~~~ COMMENT: So... if someone who's FOR regime change doesn't think that change is coming, it's hard to be too sure that regime change is coming.

Regarding the recent re-authorization of additional candidates for the February election (in both Parliament & the Assembly of experts, Iranian analysts doubt that there will be significant enough of a shift that would allow moderate/reformist candidates to gain a majority in parliament.  Given the two week & one week period for campaigning (Assembly & Parliament respectively), it is unclear how much will change.  While there is a popular perception among the electorate in Iran that gains achieved by the Nuclear deal by Reformists (which will primarily increase a popular vote for it in the election) are significant enough to not only increase electoral participation but also allow reformists/moderates to gain the majority it seeks.   Given this context, analysts suggest the following: "The composition of Parliament may very well shift further in Rouhani’s favor, but the extent to which his allies will be able to gain seats has already been significantly hampered by the Guardian Council. Similarly, the Assembly of Experts is shaping up to be comprised of members whose ideology is more aligned with Khamenei’s than Rouhani’s. Stay tuned." Looking at whether there is a resurgence among reformists in the parliamentary elections, the majority of analysts say - "Not Quite!"  Quote:  "After reportedly disqualifying 99 percent of Reformist candidates in a previous round of vetting, the Guardian Council recently announced that it has reversed the disqualifications of 1,500 unnamed candidates. These additions raise the overall number of approved candidates so far to around 6,175 -- an underwhelming 50 percent of the original 12,123 registered candidates."  In an extensive assessment, specialists note the following from statements made by key reformists/moderate leaders :
                 "It is impossible to assess the precise number of Reformist candidates until the Guardian Council releases its final list of approved candidates on February 16, but Reformist reactions have been muted, possibly indicating that the Guardian Council’s additional 1,500 candidates are not overwhelmingly Reformist and will not dramatically shift the balance of power in the elections away from hardliners. Mohammad Reza Aref, the former First Vice President under Reformist President Mohammad Khatami, bluntly told reporters that consultations with the Guardian Council were “unsuccessful” in overturning the disqualifications of key Reformist figures. Prominent Reformist newspaper Shargh, meanwhile, published an editorial claiming that the “situation of the Reformist camp does not appear hopeful” despite the overturned disqualifications. The most notable optimistic remark came from former Reformist president Mohammad Khatami, who said that “a glimmer of hope remains” that additional Reformist candidates have been confirmed." Looking forward beyond the elections, the University of Maryland has assessed the dynamics that are bound to dominate the political landscape if Reformists *were to* win a majority or not :  "A resurgent Reformist party in Iran’s new Parliament would not catalyze change in several of the most worrisome aspects of Iranian policy, however. A Parliament dominated by Rouhani supporters would be unlikely to constrain provocative Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps behavior in the Persian Gulf successfully. Support for Iranian military involvement in Syria also crosses party lines; a recent University of Maryland poll of Iranian public opinion found that a solid majority of 63 percent supports sending Iranian military personnel to Syria. An overwhelming 80 percent “approve of the role” Iran is currently playing in Syria. That is not something that a Reformist parliament would be able -- or even necessarily want -- to fix."

I began by researching what had happened in previous elections to understand the number of seats the moderates had gotten. I looked at the articles written about the number of moderate candidates that had been let into the races.  Clearly with this number of candidates they could not achieve a majority, but that wasn't the question: it was whether the conservatives could achieve a majority (at least 146 seats) This means we need to take into consideration both the moderates and the independents.  I ran a Monte Carlo simulation with the numbers from previous elections--30,000 stochastic simulations run along a gaussian curve. This gave me an 32% chance that the independents and moderates could take away enough votes to make the conservatives lose their majority if the election were fair--so a 68% chance the conservatives would maintain a majority. It's clear from the exclusion of so many moderates that the election won't be fair. This is why I looked at a scenario in which all 30 moderate candidates make it into the majles and examined what it would take for Independents to reach the required number to keep the conservatives from obtaining the majority. This is why I revised my prediction up 20 percentage points to 88%, leaving the 12% as those stochastic elements that no one can account for.

I asked about the definition of conservatives a while ago, and got this helpful response recently:  "Thank you again for your question. The question team has discussed the issue but because party and ideological identification in Iran is less structured than in the US and Europe, we decided not to provide a more concrete definition of "conservatives."   The question was framed this way to account for that fluidity, after consulting multiple Iran experts.  Although a concrete definition of "conservative" is not provided, we include two important resources to frame the issue. First, the Washington Post article in the "More Info" section. It describes "conservatives," both hardliners and traditionalists, as distinct from "moderates" which includes both reformists and centrists. Those "moderates" are not considered "conservatives" for the purposes of this question. This is why only the traditionalists and hardliners are mention in the "More Info" Section.  Second, we provided examples of media coverage from 2004 which distinguish between conservatives and reformists. We are hopeful that the the examples and the taxonomy developed by the Washington Post could ground the questions for forecasters.  As with all of our questions, we'll be using the totality of the media coverage to assess the answer. With implementation day of the nuclear deal having been reached, sanctions suspended (not lifted as widely reported; an important distinction), and access to SWIFT been granted to the Iranian regime, businesses and its electorate, it would be simple to assume that this dynamic provides greater legitimacy and popularity for Rouhani and the reformist agenda.  Had American prisoners not been released and immediate sanctions been imposed on the ballistic missile program in Iran, one may correctly assume that this would be the case leading to a larger swing in the electorate's preferences for the Majles.   Iran's Supreme Leader has allowed its foreign policy to move into a more reformist realm (in the diplomatic realm) for purposes of gaining greater legitimacy and entry into the international system (attempts to normalize its relations with the world, which incidentally is a reality yet to be attained over time), access to international markets (oil and other generalized markets)  in order to improve domestic growth, needs for domestic consumption, modernization (ie., access to improved technology and not an opening of the social and political space in order to gain greater reform in society), an additional array of benefits from the nuclear deal with the West.   With new sanctions imposed on 11 entities regarding Iran's ballistic missile program, the Iranian perception has most likely solidified as too great cost given what it (Iran) regards as costs imposed by the nuclear deal.   While little analysis has been presented to the American electorate regarding this wise an ingenious diplomatic move, silences domestic and international critics of the benefits attained under the deal nuclear deal.  Additional diplomatic and substantive gains (benefits) were attained by the 1 time 'prisoner' exchange and the subsequent move to continue imposing the necessary costs on the Iranian theocracy. I suspect that while Rouhani has achieved some substantive gains (with respect to the domestic Iranian audience), much its domestic perceptions (regarding the upcoming elections) will be shaped the role of the Supreme Leader (a singular theocratic dictator) by the constrains and opportunities imposed on Rouhani.   It will be of significant interest to see how this plays out in Iran in the next few days and weeks.   Will these event embolden the hold of the conservatives in the Majles and Iranian society?  How will it shape the role of the IRCG and internal security institutions regarding repression, detention and silencing of dissidents and reformists alike (perhaps expecting too much from the outcomes of the nuclear deal)? Regarding the parliamentary outcomes among conservative reformists (theocratic & partially secular) and conservatives (theocratic and anti-secular) is it perhaps still to early to tell how power will shift?

I wrote to GJO asking for clarification on several questions. They are researching the issue or consulting with sponsors on some of the questions but provided a definitive answer on this one, which GJO said I could share. I asked: 
"At first I thought this question was plain enough, as “conservatives” equal Principalists and include both Traditional and Neo-Principalists. Then I began to see the term “conservative realist” used on some web sites. I have no idea who those people are. But it would make a big difference in the number of seats that “conservatives” currently hold, if they are counted. Will they be included in the count of “conservatives”?" The reply from GJO: 
"We could not provide a concrete definition of "conservatives" because  party and ideological identification in Iran is less structured than in the US and Europe. The question was framed this way to account for that fluidity, after consulting multiple Iran experts.  Although a concreted definition of "conservative" is not provided, we include two important resources to frame the issue. First, the Washington Post article in the "More Info" section. It describes "conservatives," both hardliners and traditionalists, as distinct from "moderates" which includes both reformists and centrists. Those "moderates" are not considered "conservatives" for the purposes of this question. This is why only the traditionalists and hardliners are mention in the "More Info" Section.  Second, we provided examples of media coverage from 2004 which distinguish between conservative and reformists. We are hopeful that the the examples and the taxonomy developed by the Washington Post could ground the questions for forecasters.  As with all of our questions, we'll be using the totality of the media coverage to assess the answer.  Because it is such an important question and one likely to garner significant media attention we believe that this holistic approach will work.  A side note, the alternative was to not ask about the election. Since this will be one of the defining events for Iran, the middle east, and the nuclear deal, the team believed it was worth attempting even though the fluidity of Iran's system makes the question a bit more challenging. " Trying to get these people's attention, as they were discussing this issue: @einsteinjs, @dkc, @dowser, @Khalid, @rjfmgy, @argon1, @morrell, @Jean-Pierre, @Amir- There are probably more.

registered candidates for the country’s parliamentary and Assembly of Experts elections next month has surged compared with previous polls, increasing by 100% and 60%, respectively. Although the Guardian Council is unlikely to approve all candidacies,...
...surge in the number of registered candidates can be traced to five main motivating factors....Moreover, since the norm of having political parties does not exist in Iran, some only put forth candidacies because they like the idea of going to the Ministry of Interior to register and getting the related media attention. In addition, considering the rate of unemployment and economic decline in Iran, certain educated but jobless individuals believe that becoming a member of parliament is an opportunity to gain access to better economic and political opportunities....Second is the Reformists’ strategy. Supporters of the Rouhani administration, including Reformists, have adopted the strategy of introducing a lot of candidates in the hopes that if their leading figures are disqualified, lesser-known Reformists will be given the chance to run for parliament and pursue the Reformist agenda. This strategy is useful for mobilizing people in order to change the political makeup of parliament and the Assembly of Experts, both of which are currently dominated by non-Reformists. Prominent Reformists can of course wield more influence and be more effective compared to second- or third-rate colleagues. However, the Reformists are not going to give up easily. They are hoping to at least increase the political cost for the conservatives if the Guardian Council engages in mass disqualifications of registered candidates....Third is the most important political turning point of Iran in the next 10 years. There is speculation that in the next decade, considering the age of Iran’s 76-year-old, ailing Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the country will have a new leader. Considering the authority enjoyed by the supreme leader within Iran’s political system, various groups are looking to secure their positions in the Assembly of Experts, which is tasked with selecting the next supreme leader. Rafsanjani’s proposal to establish a “leadership council” instead of a single supreme leader has been criticized by the conservatives but welcomed by the Reformists and alternative political thinkers. On the other hand, if Reformists and supporters of the Rouhani administration manage to win a majority of seats in parliament, sidelined Reformists can return to politics, and thus the atmosphere of moderation and reform long promised by Rouhani can finally be institutionalized....Fourth is women’s rights campaigns....Last but certainly not least is that the outcome of the latest presidential elections continues to impact Iranian politics. The 2013 presidential vote proved that by participating in elections and supporting a certain candidate, people can overcome some of their economic and political problems. Indeed, Iranians realized that by taking part in polls and electing Rouhani, they could help solve the nuclear crisis, which had been ongoing since 2003. It should not be overlooked that a majority of people believe that they can influence the politics of their country by casting their ballots.

January 4, 2016 4:22 pm - Iran’s hardliners seize on embassy attack anger to weaken Rouhani - Najmeh Bozorgmehr in Tehran
"They took selfies and posted cheery photos on social media as if they found setting ablaze the Saudi embassy in Tehran hilarious.
Earlier, dozens of protesters chanted “Mashallah, Mashallah” — “God willed it” — as they ransacked the embassy in protest against Riyadh’s execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, a prominent Shia cleric.
The Sunni Arab kingdom responded by severing ties with Tehran, with Bahrain and Sudan following Riyadh’s example. The United Arab Emirates also downgraded relations.
At first glance, it may appear that Islamic vigilantes had created a diplomatic crisis that fuelled tensions between the two regional superpowers.
But reform-minded analysts warned that Iran’s hardliners have exploited public outrage to undermine President Hassan Rouhani and his allies.
“Without doubt, the incident is related to the current tense political infighting,” said one analyst. “More bad news will come soon. There will be a further build-up of pressure on the reformists.”
Iran struck a landmark nuclear agreement with big powers last summer, which is expected to be implemented this month. The benefits of that accord — following the lifting of economic sanctions — should increase Mr Rouhani’s leverage in Iran’s sophisticated corridors of power.
Hardliners, who were shocked to lose to Mr Rouhani in the 2013 presidential election, hope to win back support in crucial polls next month after a series of setbacks, that included the nuclear deal.
“It is hard to believe that some people threw Molotov cocktails at the Saudi embassy and confiscated it for one or two hours without being supported by some [power] centres,” said Mohammad-Sadegh Javadi-Hesar, a reformist politician. “That’s why they easily take selfies and seem confident they will be rewarded for their radical stances.”
Iran’s hardliners are mostly based in the elite Revolutionary Guard, the judiciary, parliament, state-run television and the Guardian Council, a constitutional watchdog that vets candidates’ Islamic (and political) credentials. The council is expected to bar many reformist candidates from running for the polls by questioning their allegiance to the Islamic ideology.
After nearly a decade of isolation Iran has a deal with six world powers to wind back progress towards building a nuclear bomb in exchange for a reversal of international economic sanctions
Even the grandson of the founder of the Islamic revolution, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, may not pass the tough vetting procedure. Hassan Khomeini — who is allied with reformists and whose candidacy has outraged hardliners — is obliged to take a test on Tuesday to certify he is a suitably senior cleric to enter into the Experts Assembly, which could decide on who should be Iran’s next supreme leader.
Even so, reformist analysts say that while senior political leaders may approve a crackdown on reformists, they doubt they would have given the green light to storm an embassy. The international repercussions for such a drastic move would be too severe for the country.
Even a hardline cleric such as Ahmad Khatami, who leads Tehran’s Friday prayers, condemned the attack on the embassy.
Mr Khatami said that “we don’t achieve anything by attacking embassies and setting fire to them” and that “it was not appropriate to attack the Saudi embassy and consulate ”.
If the attack leads to the barring of Iranians travelling to the Hajj pilgrimage in Mecca, it would prove particularly embarrassing for the country’s senior leaders.
Iran’s supreme leader and ultimate decision maker, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, had warned after a similar attack on the British embassy in Tehran in 2011 that diplomatic missions should enjoy complete security.
Hardliners might be staunch supporters of Iran’s supreme leader, but analysts say that they cannot resist the opportunity to weaken their rivals.
Ayatollah Khamenei cannot afford to allow severe prosecution of those embassy demonstrators as they have come to the Islamic Republic’s aid before and carried out brutal crackdowns on opposition movements.
“Hardliners need to radicalise the political and social atmosphere so they can eliminate their rivals under the pretext of national security,” Mr Javadi-Hesar added.
“Their number in various centres may be equal to a few brigades who can be quickly organised to confront people with moderate groups who are now identified with Mr Rouhani.”

Nejatollah Ebrahimian told Tasnim News Agency on Dec. 27 that the council will review all the comments and actions of the candidates during 2009 postelection protests. He said that the behavior of the candidates should not have been such that it could be construed that they participated in the illegal activities during 2009, adding they should have “clear and specific lines drawn with the sedition of 2009.” The contested 2009 presidential elections, which hard-liners refer to as the “2009 sedition,” was a turning point in Iranian elections. The incumbent, controversial hard-liner Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, was announced the victor. The Reformist candidates, Mir Hossein Mousavi and Mehdi Karroubi, challenged the results and encouraged their supporters to hold street protests — the largest since the 1979 Islamic Revolution. Despite hundreds of arrests, dozens of deaths and the house arrest of the so-called Green Movement leaders, Iranian officials responsible for the crackdown continue to raise the issue of the 2009 elections as a sort of dividing line between those who should be allowed to be part of the political process and those who should not. The Guardian Council spokesman was not the only official to discuss the 2009 elections recently. Mohammad Hussein Safar-Harandi, an adviser to the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, said Dec. 27 that Mousavi “is still under delusion and for this reason has not repented nor apologized.” Mousavi, his wife, Zahra Rahnavard, and Karroubi have been under house arrest since February 2011. While a number of the Reformists had their political careers come to an end over the 2009 elections, politicians who stayed on the fence or were perceived to have supported the Green Movement behind the scenes are most at risk of being disqualified in these current elections. Ayatollah Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, a candidate in the Assembly of Experts elections, is perhaps the most well-known political figure who is attacked by conservative media for not drawing a clear line with those who contested the elections. The odds are generally skewed in favour of conservative parliamentarians. All candidates for the Majles must be approved by Iran's Guardian Council, which is dominated by conservatives appointed by the Ayatollah and the head of the judiciary (who is also appointed by the Ayatollah). Iran's Guardian Council also has a history of disqualifying reformist candidates:  - In 2004, the "Guardian Council’s wholesale disqualification of reformist candidates, including sitting reformist lawmakers of the sixth parliament, set the stage for the return of conservatives to power in the seventh parliament" (Iran Primer). All told, the Guardian Council disqualified over 4,000 reformist hopefuls in 2004, including 80 sitting members. - In 2008, the Guardian Council continued its  "aggressive vetting of reformist candidates" (Iran Primer). The Council disqualified around 2000 candidates in 2008.   - In 2012, the election was influenced by "continued aggressive vetting and several key reformist parties’ decision not to participate" (Iran Primer). There were also widespread allegations of vote rigging and fraud.  Updating Strategy: A key election signal will be the number and type of candidates disqualified by the Guardian Council. If a significant number of reformist candidates are not allowed to run, it becomes increasingly likely that the conservatives will maintain their hold on the Majles. It will also be worth watching the number of reformist politicians that choose to register in the first place. Quite a few leading reformists decided not to participate in 2012. Candidate registration began on December 19 and will run until December 26. We should know how many are approved sometime shortly after that.  Links:

It looks like the The Guardian Council will disqualify moderate candidates if they are going to lose the conservative majority.  from this site:
https://majlismonitor.com/en/2015/11/how-the-guardian-council-could-shape-irans-2016-parliamentary-election/ "The Guardian Council plays a mix of quasi-judicial and -legislative roles in Iran’s political system, including vetting presidential, parliamentary and Assembly of Experts candidates and reviewing legislation to ensure compliance with the constitution and Islamic law. The dispute over the Council’s role began this past August 19th when President Rouhani fired the first shot in a speech calling on the body to play a purely supervisory role in elections, saying that it is an “eye” that “cannot do the job of a hand”. Highlighting the Council’s practice of disqualifying entire political groups in recent years, Rouhani said that all legal groups should be respected and individual candidates judged on their merits rather than political affiliations." "This concern notably applies to reformists who, prior to the controversial 2009 presidential elections, had often found themselves under the Guardian Council’s ax. Following the reformist-led 2009 post-election demonstrations and its subsequent suppression, potential 2012 parliamentary election reformist candidates were either in prison, exile, or opted to boycott the vote. After largely ending their boycott of elections in the 2013 presidential election, it remains to be seen whether the Council will allow reformists to participate this time around. With a nuclear victory in hand, Iran’s president must now look to fulfill promises made in the 2013 presidential election campaign to expand domestic social and political freedoms. However, his efforts have been obstructed by Iran’s conservative parliament. If the Guardian Council disqualifies moderate candidates and groups en masse, the prospects for advancing this domestic agenda will be thrown in danger."
